Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [telegram] <burfy174> KMD vs aeternity??

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [telegram] <burfy174> Competitor's or place for both within the market?

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [telegram] <burfy174> I've asked about the project and they say KMD doesn't have state channels or oracles, making it inferior.... Can anyone address this

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [matrix] <jl777:matrix.org> KMD has notary nodes which can create data that performs the function of an oracle, ie. notarizations, MoM, that enables the cross chain contracts. As far as state channels go, what exactly is meant by that and what functionality does it enable that is not possible otherwise?

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [matrix] <jl777:matrix.org> To my thinking being able to execute arbitrary complexity computations in a dedicated blockchain (nodes validating that chain) and then using the result of that in any other chain, is quite a flexible architecture that is able to implement essentially any decentralization solution. After we get the basics in place we will demonstrate this with a decentralized poker solution. Instead of working on fancy buzzwords, we simply are working on solving the actual problems of scaling

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [matrix] <jl777:matrix.org> there are so many projects that are solving a subset of what needs to be solved. scaling without security is not any scaling solution. To my knowledge no other scaling solution is using full bitcoin protocol transactions, ie. even atomic swaps, that ends up with BTC level security

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [matrix] <jl777:matrix.org> in addition to arbitrary scaling, BTC security, we get zcash privacy, and again I am not away of anybody that does even 2 of the 3: Scaling, Security and Privacy. And all the other platforms require locking into the main coin's usage. While in the short term this might look good, it is not sustainable long term. After all, who wants to pay $5 for a $1 transaction, just because some game app is being popular at the time

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [matrix] <jl777:matrix.org> The other scaling solutions start from one large blockchain and are trying to shard it into different pieces (how is each piece secured?). With KMD there never is any single large blockchain, things start out in their own dedicated blockchain, so there is no need to solve the sharding problem, it is already segregated into the different blockchains that contain only info that is of interest to that blockchain

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [matrix] <jl777:matrix.org> dPoW and notarization of the MoM data then allows doing cross chain contracts between any chains in a cluster of chains

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [matrix] <jl777:matrix.org> Basically KMD achieves the Scaling + Security + Privacy solution with a minimum of new cutting edge tech that might or might not stand the test of time. Even the cross chain contracts is using SPV techniques known from the original satoshi whitepaper. The independent blockchains are using time tested bitcoin protocol codebase (as forked by zcash)

Author: Gateway#3763
Content:
[telegram] <Matt> Privacy is getting slashed and unwanted by govs and regulators.
Sadly enough.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [matrix] <jl777:matrix.org> yes, that is why KMD is using optional privacy. using KMD doesnt force people to use the privacy so that should keep it one step away from the regulators, especially since there are lots of other uses for KMD than "just" privacy, even if privacy will become as important as security in the coming years

Author: Gateway#3763
Content:
[telegram] <burfy174> So it's there in the background, able to be used, but also able to be left if long term regulations see privacy as a pitfall.
Thank you for all the info you provided. Really appreciate the detailed write up! (re @Matterbridge_kmdbot: [matrix] <jl777:matrix.org> yes, that is why KMD is using optional privacy. using KMD doesnt force people to use the privacy so that should keep it one step away from the regulators, especially since there are lots of other uses for KMD than "just" privacy, even if privacy will become as important as security in the coming years)

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [matrix] <jl777:matrix.org> the privacy is there for the people who feel that it is important to them, but it is totally optional, so using KMD does not mean you are using privacy, since some (most?) countries view privacy as the equivalent of having committed crimes

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [telegram] <LAP> I have a question. If 32 of the 64 public notary nodes are hacked, will not dPOW be hacked?

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [telegram] <LAP> Or what happens if a hacker owns 32 notarized nodes?

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [telegram] <LAP> Is this a weakness of dPOW?

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [telegram] <barbierir> that would left 32 notaries working, the bare minimum is 13 notaries doing their job

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [matrix] <jl777:matrix.org> hacked notaries still cannot make illegal notarizations, as all nodes validate all notarizations

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [telegram] <eos> https://t.co/BD4dznBsyz

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [matrix] <jl777:matrix.org> the most that can be done by compromised notarizes is to withhold notarizations. so it isnt a hack per se, but a disruption

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [matrix] <jl777:matrix.org> that being said the notarization algo requires just 13 to be online to notarized, but if more than 13 are online, then a highly randomized process is used to select the 13

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [matrix] <jl777:matrix.org> something like 50 notaries of 64 would need to be compromised to prevent the remaining to create notarizations

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [matrix] <jl777:matrix.org> due to the extremely small chance of this happening and even if it does happen, it is obvious from the lack of notarizations, I wouldnt call this a weakness as any system that is 75%+ compromised will likely not work too well

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [matrix] <jl777:matrix.org> notarization is not about creating blocks, but rather for 13 randomly selected notaries to agree on a recent blockhash and saving it to the BTC blockchain, in addition to the KMD chain
